section.title: SCCP Management Commands
section.para: SCCP provides connectionless and connection-oriented network services. This includes address(GTT) translation and routing, flow control segmentation and reassembly.

A global title is an address (e.g., a dialed 800 number, calling card number, or mobile subscriber identification number) which is translated by SCCP into a destination point code and subsystem number. A subsystem number uniquely identifies an application at the destination signaling point. SCCP is used as the transport layer for TCAP -based services

The first step for SCCP configuring is a service access points (sap) definition. This step is mandatory. Each SCCP stack can use one or more Mtp3UserPart (Refer about Mtp3UserPart setting). A sap is a logical definition of the Mtp3UserPart (corresponded local SPC, network indicator (NI) and a set of destinations (remote SPC list)). The index of a sap must correspont to the index of the sap.

The second step is a definition of a list of available remote signaling pointcodes (SPC - rsp) and a list of available remote Sub-Systems (SNN - rss). This step is also mandatory. If routing only by GlobalTytle is used the remote Sub-Systems configuring is not required.

As SCCP acts as message router, it requires means to configure routing information. Rules (rule), primary (primary_add) and backup (backup_add) (if backup addresses are available) addresses should be configured.

If XUDT and LUDT messages are availavle in the SS7 network, user should config a set of long message rules (lmr) that will allow long messages. This step is not mandatory. If no long message rule is configured only UDT messages will be used.
The last step is also optional. A user can configure a set of concerned signaling point codes (csp). Each point code will be announced when local SCCP user becomes (un)available.
User can also configure general SCCP parameters (Refer about general parameters setting).

section.title: Service access points and destinations management
section.para: SCCP service access points (sap) and destinations (dest) are managed by sccp sap and sccp dest commands. They allows to perform following:

section.title: Create service access point
section.para: Sap can be created by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: A unique number to identify this sap
A Mtp3UserPart index that is used as an index of mtp3UserPart property for SccpStack bean. Refer to for details. For each Mtp3UserPart a sap must be configured.
Specifies the local signaling point code.
Specifies the network indicator that forms the part of service information octet (SIO)

section.para: For each of sap one or more destinations should be configured. Refer to for details.

example.title: SCCP sap creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp sap create 1 1 101 2 telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp sap create 2 2 102 2

section.title: Modify existing sap
section.para: Sap can be modified by issuing command with following structure:
Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete SCCP service access point
section.para: SCCP sap can be deleted by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: is id set during sap creation

example.title: SCCP sap Removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp sap delete 1 Service access point successfully removed

section.title: Show SCCP service access point
section.para: Saps can be viewed by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: id is optional. If passed only sap matching the id will be shown, else all the saps will be shown

section.title: Create destination for service access point
section.para: Destination can be created by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: An identifier of the sap for which the destination is being created
A number to identify this destination. The number must be unique for each sap.
Specifies the first value of the remote signaling point codes range.
Specifies the last value of the remote signaling point codes range. If destination specifies a single signaling point code, this value must be equal first-dpc
Specifies the first value of the SLS range.
Specifies the last value of the SLS range.
Specifies the mask value. SLS af a message will be exposed by bitwise AND operation with this mask before comparing with first-sls and last-sls valuers.

section.para: SLS value range is from 0 to 255. If the destination cover all possible SLS's use first-sls=0, last-sls=255, sls-mask=255

section.title: Modify existing destination for service access point
section.para: Destination can be modified by issuing command with following structure:
Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete SCCP destination for service access point
section.para: SCCP destination can be deleted by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: An identifier of the sap for which the destination has been created
is id set during destination creation

example.title: SCCP destination Removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp destination delete 1 1 Destination definition successfully deleted

section.title: Show SCCP destination for service access point
section.para: Destinations can be viewed by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: An identifier of the sap for which the destination has been created
id is optional. If passed only destination matching the id will be shown, else all destinations of the saps will be shown

section.title: Rule Management
section.para: SCCP routing rules are managed by sccp rule command. It allows to perform following:

section.title: Create Rule
section.para: A Rule can be created by issuing command with following structure:
This command should be specified after primary_add and backup_add are configured. Please refer on how to configure primary_add and backup_add

listitem.para: A unique number to identify this rule

mask defines which part of the originally dialed digits remains in the translated digits and which part is replaced by the digits from primary or backup address. mask is divided into sections by separator /. The number of sections in mask should be equal to sections in digits passed in this command and sections in primary or backup address

row.entry: Separator used to split the mask into sections.
Keep the original dialed digits of this section into translated digits
Replace the original dialed digits of this section with same section from primary or backup address into translated digits

listitem.para: The address indicator is the first field in SCCP Party Address(called/calling) and is one octet in length. Its function is to indicate which information elements are present so that the address can be interpreted, in other words, it indicates the type of addressing information that is to be found in the address field. The addressing information from original global title is then compared with passed address information to match the rule.
Point code. This is ignored if bit 0 of address-indicator is not set.
Subsystem Number. This is ignored if bit 1 of address-indicator is not set.
Translation type. This is ignored if GT Indicator is 0000 or 0001
The Number Plan (NP) field specifies the numbering plan that the address information follows. This is ignored if GT Indicator is 0000, 0001 or 0010
The Nature of Address Indicator (NAI) field defines the address range for a specific numbering plan. This is only used if GT Indicator is 0100
Specifies the string of digits divided into subsections using separator '/' depending on if mask contains separator. The dialed digits should match with theses digits as per rule specified bellow

row.entry: wildcard - matches any number of digits
sparator used to split the digit pattern into sections. Each section can be processed differently as specified by mask parameter.

listitem.para: Rule type. One of following values is possible.

row.entry: Only one (primary) address is used for routing (<backup-address-id> may be missed in this case).
Both (primary and backup) addresses are used and mandatory. If both of addresses are available the primary address is used for routing.

Both (primary and backup) addresses are used and mandatory. If both of addresses are available either primary or backup address is used for routing. The <loadsharing-algorithm> should be configured in this case.

listitem.para: Identifies the SCCP Address used as the primary translation

Identifies the SCCP Address used as the backup translation in case if pointcode specified by primary address is not available. Backup address is optional and is used only with dominant and loadshared address types
This parameter is mandatory only if <ruleType> parameter is "loadshared". Loadsharing algorithm is configured here. Possible values of the parameter:

entry.para: if( (SLS & 0x01) == 0 ) <route to primary> else <route to backup>
This algorithm can be used if not all traffic is locally (TelScale stack) originated. But only 8 links in both the linksets are acceptable.
if( (SLS & 0x02) == 0 ) <route to primary> else <route to backup>
This algorithm can be used if not all traffic is locally (TelScale stack) originated. But only 8 links in both the linksets are acceptable.
if( (SLS & 0x04) == 0 ) <route to primary> else <route to backup>
This algorithm can be used if not all traffic is locally (TelScale stack) originated. But only 8 links in both the linksets are acceptable.
if( (SLS & 0x08) == 0 ) <route to primary> else <route to backup>
This algorithm can be used if not all traffic is locally (TelScale stack) originated. But only 8 links in both the linksets are acceptable.
if( (SLS & 0x10) == 0 ) <route to primary> else <route to backup>
This algorithm is the best if all traffic is locally (TelScale stack) originated

example.title: SCCP Rule creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp rule create 1 R 71 2 8 0 0 3 123456789 solitary 1 telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp rule create 2 R 71 2 8 0 0 3 123456789 dominant 1 1 telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp rule create 2 R 71 2 8 0 0 3 123456789 loadshared 1 1 bit4

section.para: Rule can be modified by issuing command with following structure:
Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete SCCP Rule

example.title: SCCP Rule Removal

section.title: Address Management
section.para: The command is used to define primary or backup address of translation. The global title address information of this command is combined with the global title being translated by examining the mask provided in the sccp rule create command.The syntax remains same except for primary address sccp primary_add is used and for backup address sccp backup_add is used

section.title: Create Address
section.para: Address can be created by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: For primary address
For backup address
A unique number to identify this address

The address indicator is the first field in SCCP Party Address(called/calling) and is one octet in length. Its function is to indicate which information elements are present so that the address can be interpreted, in other words, it indicates the type of addressing information that is to be found in the address field. The addressing information from original global title is then compared with passed address information to match the rule.
Point code. This is ignored if bit 0 of address-indicator is not set.
Subsystem Number. This is ignored if bit 1 of address-indicator is not set.
Translation type. This is ignored if GT Indicator is 0000 or 0001
The Number Plan (NP) field specifies the numbering plan that the address information follows. This is ignored if GT Indicator is 0000, 0001 or 0010
The Nature of Address Indicator (NAI) field defines the address range for a specific numbering plan. This is only used if GT Indicator is 0100
The global title address information to translate to, specified as string of digits divided into subsections using separator '/' depending on if mask contains separator.
In addition the digits string can contain

row.entry: Separtor to split the digits into sections. Each section is processed differently as specified by the mask in sccp rule create command.

example.title: SCCP Primary Address creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp primary_add create 1 71 2 8 0 0 3 123456789

example.title: SCCP Backup Address creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp backup_add create 1 71 3 8 0 0 3 123456789

section.title: Modify existing Address
section.para: Address can be modified by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: For primary address
For backup address

section.para: Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete Address

listitem.para: For primary address
For backup address

section.para: Where:

listitem.para: is id set during address creation

example.title: Primary Address Removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp primary_add delete 1 Rule successfully removed

example.title: Backup Address Removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp backup_add delete 1 Rule successfully removed

section.para: Address's can be viewed by issuing command with following structure:

For backup address

section.para: Where:

listitem.para: id is optional. If passed only address matching the id will be shown, else all the addresses will be shown

section.title: Remote Signaling Point Management
section.para: SCCP resources includes remote signaling point and remote subsystem. Each remote signaling point that SCCP can communicate with must be configured using sccp rsp command

section.title: Create Remote Signaling Point
section.para: Remote signaling point can be create by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: A unique number to identify this remote signaling point
The remote signaling point
32 bit value. Not used for now. Reserved for future
32 bit value. Not used for now. Reserved for future

example.title: Remote Signalin Point creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp rsp create 1 6477 0 0

section.title: Modify existing Remote Signaling Point
section.para: Remote Signaling Point can be modified by issuing command with following structure:
Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete Remote Signaling Point
section.para: Where:

listitem.para: is id set during remote signaling point creation

example.title: Remote Signaling Point removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp rsp delete 1

section.title: Show Remote Signaling Point/s
section.para: Remote signaling point can be viewed by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: id is optional. If passed only remote signaling point matching the id will be shown, else all the addresses will be shown

section.title: Remote Sub-System Management
section.para: SCCP resources includes remote signaling point and remote subsytem. Each remote subsystem that SCCP can communicate with must be configured using sccp rss command
This command should be specified after remote signaling point is configured. Please refer on how to configure remote signaling point

section.title: Create Remote Sub-System
section.para: Remote subsystem can be created by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: A unique number to identify this remote subsystem
The remote signaling point where this remote susbsytem is deployed
The remote subsystem number
32 bit value. Not used for now. Reserved for future

This parameter is optional, its possible value is: prohibitedWhenSpcResuming. When this parameter is present configured subsystem is marked as prohibited when its corresponded signaling point code has been resumed.

example.title: Remote Sub-System creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp rss create 1 6477 8 0 prohibitedWhenSpcResuming

section.title: Modify existing Remote Sub-System
section.para: Remote Sub-System can be modified by issuing command with following structure:
Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete Remote Sub-System
section.para: Where:

listitem.para: is id set during remote subsystem creation

example.title: Remote Sub-System removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp rss delete 1

section.title: Show Remote Sub-System/s
section.para: Remote subsystem can be viewed by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: id is optional. If passed only remote subsystem matching the id will be shown, else all will be shown

section.title: Long message rules Management
section.para: Long message rules describe which message types (UDT/XUDT/LUDT) will be used for outgoing message encoding depends on dpc. If no long message rules is configured only UDT messages will be used.

section.title: Create Long message rule
section.para: Long message rule can be created by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: A unique number to identify this Long message rule
Specifies the first value of the remote signaling point codes range. (for which Long message rule will apply)
Specifies the last value of the remote signaling point codes range. If Long message rule specifies a single signaling point code, this value must be equal first-spc.
Specifies which message types will be used for the remote signaling point codes range. Possible values are: udt, xudt and ludt.

example.title: Long message rule creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp lmr create 1 201 201 xudt telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp lmr create 2 230 239 udt

section.title: Modify existing Long message rule
section.para: Long message rule can be modified by issuing command with following structure:
Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete Modify existing Long
section.para: Where:

listitem.para: is id set during Long message rule creation

example.title: Long message rule removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp lmr delete 1

section.title: Show Long message rule/s
section.para: Long message rule can be viewed by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: id is optional. If passed only Long message rule matching the id will be shown, else all the rules will be shown

section.title: Concerned signaling point codes Management
section.para: Concerned signaling point codes define a DPC list which will be noticed when local SSN is registered (SSA messages) or unregistered (SSP messages).

section.title: Create Concerned signaling point code
section.para: Concerned signaling point codes can be created by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: A unique number to identify this Concerned signaling point code
Specifies the value of the remote signaling point code, which will be noticed.

example.title: Concerned signaling point code creation
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp csp create 1 201 telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp csp create 2 202

section.title: Modify existing Concerned signaling point code
section.para: Concerned signaling point code can be modified by issuing command with following structure:
Meaning of parameters is the same.

section.title: Delete Concerned signaling point code
section.para: Where:

listitem.para: is id set during Concerned signaling point code creation

example.title: Concerned signaling point code removal
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp csp delete 1

section.title: Show Concerned signaling point code/s
section.para: Concerned signaling point code can be viewed by issuing command with following structure:
Where:

listitem.para: id is optional. If passed only Concerned signaling point code matching the id will be shown, else all the codes will be shown

section.title: General parameters
section.para: User can set several general parameters that influence the whole SCCP stack.

row.entry: If the XUDT message data length greater this value, segmentation is processed. Otherwise no segmentation.
SCCP segmented message reassembling timeout (in milliseconds).
Enable or disable ability to be relay node with coupling.
SCCP connection IT send timeout (in milliseconds).
SCCP connection message receive timeout (in milliseconds).
SCCP connection release complete message timeout (in milliseconds).
SCCP connection released message repeat timeout (in milliseconds).
SCCP connection resources release timeout (in milliseconds).
SCCP connection work resume after restart timeout (in milliseconds).
SCCP connection release after reset timeout (in milliseconds).
Thread count in SCCP connections timers thread pool.
Max available SCCP message data for all message types.

Remove PC from calledPartyAddress when sending to MTP3. After Global Title Translation, if the SCCP address includes the destination point code (DPC) however Address Indicator (AI) indicates route on Global Title and removeSpc is set to true, DPC will be removed from SCCP Address. The same rule applies for both calling as well as called party SCCP Address.
Max (after increasing) SST sending interval (in milliseconds).
Multiplicator of SST sending interval (next interval will be greater the current by sstTimerDuration_IncreaseFactor). This value has type "double".

section.title: General parameters setting
section.para: General parameter can be set by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: A mnemonic name of a parameter.
A value of a parameter.

example.title: General parameters setting
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp set zMarginXudtMessage 230 telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp set removeSpc false

section.title: General parameters getting
section.para: General parameter can be got by issuing command with following structure:

listitem.para: A mnemonic name of a parameter. This parameter is optional. If a mnemonic name is absent all parameter values will be returned.

example.title: General parameters getting
example.screen: telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp get zMarginXudtMessage telscale(10.65.208.215:3435)>sccp get
